posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.sub: things that make you slightly upset
posts.com:
I like my car, and I like Lexus. But some of their design choices are questionable at best.
For example, I changed my lightbulbs on my IS250 yesterday, and in order to even get access to the headlights, you had to remove the air intake, including of course the MAF[sensor].
Did that, switched the lights, all good, they light up- start the engine-
>pic related
Now usually, when you drive around for a couple of miles/km's, these warning lights disappear from the dash, but not in a Lexus, no. You have to either take it to the stealership (to do a simple 5 minute thing like changing the lightbulb) so they can charge you extra for "deleting the ECU errors".
It's fine by me, I can delete these errors my self, but what if I couldn't?
It's a small thing but this is still a shitty practice.

What are your small stories that upset you slightly?

>>26233736
My issue with subaru after 2019 is their use of the massive tablet infotainment especially as they hide many controls behind that computer. This is exactly the opposite of their previous gens which had screens but all of the controls were still physical and the screen only controlled media stuff. My second issue is with the CVT. While Subaru has made strides in improving their CVT reliability my big issues have always been the inconsistent power delivery in questionable conditions. The CVT computer or computer systems as a whole are known to refuse to transmit power purely to prevent a high load from being transferred through the CVT. It'll either use TCS to reduce throttle or the TCU will disengage the torque converter. The engine will rev incessantly but none of that power makes it to the wheels.

At 38k USD thats a lot of money for the cheapest XT. Thats basically top trim for most other economy car makers. I would still prefer other cars like the Rav4 hybrid because its AWD system is just as good for any realistic scenario and it gets a fuck ton better gas mileage.

Retard.
When you have to sell a gorillion cars to recoup the development costs, car manufacturers will trim their model lines down to ensure each individual model sells as many as possible. Nissan literally cannot afford to have 3 different mid-size saloon options that share essentially no components with each other. The reason they could 30 years ago is because cars cost much less to make, meaning they could afford to make a variety of things that sell comparatively less because they’d still turn a profit.

So yes, it is actually impossible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237449
Old brake fluid floats on top of new fluid. Remove as much as you can, fill with fresh fluid, let the gunk float to the top and then repeat until reservoir is clear, then flush the rest of your brake system normally

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26237901
+1 on Everstarts.

There’s only a couple OEMs that make all of those batteries for the parts stores and big box retailers. I have used them all in the fleet of cars I’m always taking care of. They all last like +/-3mos of the warranty period, could be a Duralast Gold or DieHard or Everstart.

Everstarts at Walmart are always like 30% cheaper than the auto parts stores. Like the Gold (4yrs?) at Walmart is the same price as the standard (3yr) at the auto parts stores. Plus the Everstart 3 year warranty is a real 3 year warranty. Some of the parts stores like AutoZone prorate the last year, so Duralast 3 year warranty batteries are really only 2 year free replacement. If a $160 Duralast 3yr dies at 2 years 9 months, they will give you $40 towards the new battery. It pissed me off so much the one time I called to see if a dead battery was still under warranty, guy on the phone told me it was, but it was only like 2 months left and I got $25 towards the new one, it would’ve been cheaper to go to Walmart where the battery was like $40 cheaper.

Also Walmart has easy returns. They will go by the sticker on the battery if you don’t have a receipt, and most of the time they don’t even test it. I’ve heard lots of stories of AutoZone dudes wanting to put it on a charger overnight and dragging ass to replace batteries under warranty.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26238794
And if you get shit from one Walmart manager, just go back when their shift ends.

I really hate supporting Walmart, but you can get an Everstart Gold with a real 4 year warranty in most sizes that costs about the same as a Duralast standard with a 2 year replacement + 1 year prorated. Since I’m in Florida with the heat and AC blasting and lots of short commutes, that full warranty helps because literally the past 10 batteries I have replaced are all within a couple months of the warranty date. So buying them from Walmart, the ones that die at 34-35 months get replaced for free which saves me $$$.

Autozone is also a shit show, sometimes you have a battery that’s losing power slowly and if you load test a big 900CCA truck battery with a basic tester, it might not drop much with a 100A load but struggles to start the vehicle. And dumb Autozone kids might hesitate to replace it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26239129
It really depends.
Just the ball joints will be cheaper, but you need a press, and you need to be 100% sure the ball joints are positioned correctly.
Most of the time, you'll also have to take the control arms out.
Myself, I find it easier to just replace the whole control arms, and start anew. Control arms aren't really expensive, but I guess it depends on the car.
Your call really. Just my 2 cents.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26238910
Where did you get it tested? The kids at the auto parts stores can be retarded.

But you could have a bad starter or a bad connection anywhere between the starter and battery as well. Time to break out the multimeter. The annoying thing is you’re not really going to be able to test resistance easily because resistance with a couple mA like the meter reads is different than starting the car with hundreds of amps. Maybe you can probe some different spots along the circuit while cranking the starter? I’m sure some Youtube genius knows more than me.

Either way you should have a multimeter. See what kind of voltage you get at the battery as you’re cranking the engine. HF also has 100A carbon pile load testers for cheap, and Amazon has the new Chinese digital ones for $25-$50, but a multimeter will test more than just the battery.

>>26234831
Changing a clutch is easy. You just drop the trans or pull the engine. Whichever is easier (usually the trans). It's just you being resilient against figuring things out, getting demoralized, or not being confident/understanding what you're doing.

Like this.
1. Gain access to areas surrounding transmission by removing necessary parts.

2. Remove connections to transmission (wires, any hoses, etc.)

3. Disconnect slave cylinder if necessary as well and prep out a day for a friend to help you bleed, or just use a bottle with a tube, must be back fillable.

4. Separate transmission from motor and remove clutch.

5. Replace or resurface flywheel. Do not replace clutch without.

6. Change pilot bearing, throw out bearing, and whatever else is in there. Clean inside bell housing. Torque everything to spec.

7. Reverse of assembly.

Boom done. Now stop being an emotional idiot and do it like God intended. Don't get emotional if you don't know, just use your head. Bolts hold the transmission to the engine, you may need a pet bar tosl separate the two, and I'd recommend a jack to raise and lower the transmission. Centering and aligning the input shaft on the trans to the crankshaft/clutch can be trying but you'll get it. Just use your head.

posts.com:
In a "bold" attempt at shitbox dress shoe design, the 1947 Davis Divan was an attempt at the three-wheeled car that ultimately ended in a similar vein as the Reliant Robin did in the UK, just a good thirty years prior to what is called the "Fiberglass Pig."

Its main selling point was its extremely good fuel economy for the day due to it being lightweight, and its ability to do tight donuts at a circumference of around 17 ft thanks to its single front wheel design. Its flaws, should be obvious even if they're to be considered "design choices."

Around fifty remain from the original production line as of today. The OP's picture is from 2021 in Amelia Island, Florida where three Divan curators took their pieces of garbage to an airstrip to drag race at a blistering 50mph for a hundred dollar grand prize. The airport was well aware of the stunt and endorsed it.

Because it's funny.

The head is probably cracked, the cylinder liner gaskets don't seal for shit, the valve stem bores are worn, it burns both coolant and oil, the dizzy was out of adjustment and it was running rich as I've overjetted the carb and never bothered to jet it down.
The CO2 limit is 1000, I think it was measured in mg/KM or some shit like that.
The exhaust manifold is a 2 tube one, divided in cylinders 1-3 and 2-4 if memory serves.
Cylinders 1-3 had a CO2 value of about 2800 or so, cylinders 2-4 had under 500, good thing it has a proper dual exhaust system so they just measured from the 2nd pipe and called it a day, otherwise they would've bounced it back immediately.

This engine is barely held together and now that it passed emissions it doesn't really have to, I'm gonna take it to get structurally inspected and drop in a "big block" 1.3 litre engine from a newer FWD Skoda and later on put an Aisin supercharger next to it.
I am not going to register the modifications as the car will be "grandfathered" on the 12th of this month as it will be 40 years or older, thus I get a 2 year long inspection slip, so that's 2 years worth of time with unregistered modifications

VAN TREASURE HUNT UPDATE:
This sort of applies as a classic, even though this thing was manufactured in 1992 Brazil. >To adjust float level on an Edelbrock, turn the top upside down and measure the distance from the tip of the float to the air horn gasket; it should be 7/16-inch. If adjustments are necessary, carefully bend the arm on the float with needle nose pliers.
That way is shit and never guarantees the fuel level is correct, which affects fuel delivery through the carb.

Remove weep hole plug and screw the need and seat up or down until fuel level is at the weep hole.

I would imagine so, if you're switching from one to the other, but it's not like adding 200g to an otherwise comfortable helmet would make it feel awful.

Going from my road helmet to my dirt one is about 400g and that feels massive and I do prefer having something that light, but I don't mind the heavier one either. However if it was 400g the other way that could feel pretty bad at nearly 2kg, not for the weight increase per se but because that's a significant amount of weight for the neck to support.

tldr; aim for around 1500g, a lot heavier could be tiring, lighter probably isn't worth the extra cost

>>26239313
HJC keeps costs down on the C70 by only making two shell sizes. XS-S-M is the same helmet with different liners, as is L-XL-2XL. This is more efficient than the usual three-shell scheme.
This means if you wear M, it's going to look svelt on your head and have a thin comfort liner. If you wear L it's going to look a little bigger, and you will enjoy a very plush interior.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26241426
yeah. took a day or two to nail the basics down. lots of stalling at lights and waving to the driver behind me kek. At one point while learning I was starting to regret swapping to a manual because I kept feeling like shit holding up everyone behind me.
one bro in a hilux must've put two and two together because he waved back three times in a sort of 'it's cool mate shit happens'
But there was no way I was going to put the auto back lol so I just kept at it. Once i realised i could increase the margin before the engine stalled by just keeping the revs at 1500-2000 rpm and slowly releasing the clutch at the same time, i think that was the moment where another anon in a recent thread described learning to drive manual as
>you keep practising until one day it randomly clicks and you never unlearn how to drive a manual ever again
i did about 2000 km in the past week or so just driving everywhere and nowhere and having an absolute blast. People kept telling me that manuals will suck in stop start traffic but honestly I didn't find it too bad. Just figure out the pace at which you can just crawl along.
Now it's a matter of refining the technique. Have gotten better and better at revmatching, but it'll be a while yet until i can do the manual racing memes like heel toe shifting and all that
pic related was when I initially installed the pedals. looked wonky as you can see, thankfully my work had a hydraulic metal bender which allowed me to get the pedals at the perfect position

>>26241465
give yourself about a week if you've never done it before, are doing it solo, and are relying on a floor jack instead of a gearbox jack
if i was trying to speedrun it i could've gotten it done in 2-3 days, but i was taking my time and im a horribly unfit nerd so i didn't work into the night etc. spent about 5-6 hours tops each day going at it.
Actually took about 9 months to build up the parts and i definitely overpaid on some of them but fuck it, im gonna drive this thing till the wheels fall off. then im gonna put them back on and drive it again
on a side note, the speedo no longer works because the little spring clip (pic related) that holds the speedo drive gear in place on the output shaft, has lost tension after 20 or so odd years of doing its thing. so i have to drop the gearbox again to replace it because it requires taking off the back half of the tranny. Once parts arrive, I'm going to go to a DIY garage because it's so much easier when you have an actual tranny jack. I've been gauging my speed with the tacho though. Really I just like to have everything working. While I'm at it I also have to replace the output shaft seal and revert back to the stock mk3 supra shifter retainer, because the sc300 one i used is a bit too far back. Anyone need it? I can sell the both the retainer and the shift lever arm

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26229087
I work for a large sheriff's department in a very large, rich, liberal county. The county government wants to switch all county vehicles to electric - including police vehicles.

They have been flirting with the F-150 Lightning - however the battery issues and charging logistics are a major obstacle for them to be issued as patrol vehicles.

We use mainly 17-22 Explorers now for patrol, with a few Tahoes and F-150s out there. In rural districts refueling is already an issue with the amount of driving you do between calls. Add in a pursuit or a high speed code run, you are burning through extraordinary amounts of fuel.

We have to be able to refuel quickly - we can't have an EV where the refueling isn't instant. Plus, how are they going to factor in people charging the EVs at home? Are they going to pay a portion of peoples power bills, install charging stations at everyone's homes? etc.

This questions need to be answered. Right now maybe detectives and admin will get EVs. I can't see patrol cops getting them en masse.

On first gen Twingos there were only 3 engine options: the old pushrod C3G (55hp, before 1996), the D7F (60hp, 1996 and up), and the 16V D4F (75hp, after 2000).

Avoid anything that's not a regular old manual.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been looking at part numbers, spec sheets and compatibility charts again.
Turns out the brake setup on the Espace 1/2 is very similar to the Clio Williams, which is identical to the one found on late 16V Twingos (same caliper mounting hole spacing, same brake disc diameter, they even take the same brake pads), but with one crucial difference: the Espace calipers get much bigger pistons (54mm vs 48mm).
They also cost less than 50 eurobucks a pop brand new. Might need a new master cylinder to compensate for the increased pedal travel but this is all very promising, it's not quite a big brake kit but it should all still just barely fit under 14" wheels and get you some extra stopping power.

Also if you upgrade to 15x6-7" wheels you can run Goodyear Eagle F1s in 195/45R15, which sounds hilarious for trackday sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226818
Oh and forgot to mention, if they work on the mk1 they should also work all the way up to the mk2 GT, the RS gets bigger discs and different 57mm calipers, from the Laguna I believe.

posts.com: I need some recs. I recently moved to NE Wyoming from the PNW and holy FUCK the snow and wind here is brutal. I have a 2013 FJ; I added some big KC fogs on the bumper for the rain and fog of the PNW and they helped a ton. However, they don't do much, if at all, for some of the insane snow and white out conditions here. Normally I try to avoid when the weather is this bad, but I got stuck in it twice and visibility was dick. What would be some good, functional lights I could mount to help? I know orange helps in white conditions, but I really don't have much room at all left on my bumper to mount any. I do have spots on top of my roof near my rack where I could easily make two brackets to put two big ones up there. I am new to this, so any help would be appreciated. Not a fan of the shitty Chinese light bar looks and would prefer to stay to two round lights-they go with the retro/round lights already on the FJ and lightbars with little square LEDs look out of place. However, I am pragmatic above all else, so if a light bar would be best I would gladly just do that.

posts.name: BigC

>>26241081
do not mount the lights to the roof if you wanna see shit
they will simply illuminate the fog and blind your worse than no lights at all
you'll be looking through the beam of light
you want the fog lights low, you do not want to be looking through your light beam, you want to be as offset as possible from the lights in order to maximize visibility in fogs
trust me on this, i have roof mounted lights and in the snow or fog they make driving harder, you want bumper mounted lights, lower is better, in fog and snow

posts.name: BigC
posts.com:

if you're driving in clear weather, roof mounted is the best however, you will not see shadows cast like when lights are mounted below eye level
with lights below eye level, you can't tell if the shadow ahead is a 1 inch from or a 10 foot drop on a dirt road
in fog however, the roof lights are worse than useless, they will fucking blind you

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also, just for Europeans: given the immense demand for drivers, and the shittiness of most trucking company managers, licensing is usually more of a suggestion than a hard requirement. Most trucking companies don't even see or know the customer, they just move from terminal to terminal with all the loads handled by a third party broker run out of some guy's basement. So long as the load isn't hazmat or overweight, 99% of trailers aren't, the goal is to pick it up from yard A and drop it at yard B. LTLs or the customer itself does the last mile work, either by picking up the trailer themselves or having it crossdocked into one of theirs. LTLs and similar fleets are extremely pissy over who they hire because of this, as they have to interact with customers and do customer service. Even if the "customer service" is just not putting 20 pallets of ice cream in the parking lot expecting the cashiers to deal with it.

This is different across states, liberal states are full of Unions, Teamsters and other Communists that force things like hard licensing requirements, ID checks at weigh stations, safety, and periodic drug testing. Most companies don't bother. Most companies don't even bother with paper checks or direct deposit anymore, they just pay using a comdata card, venmo or western union. There's different flavors and all of them combine on the highway.

>implying electric vehicle charging is in anyway wide spread, convenient or fast.
Yes it is. At least if you own a Tesla like I do. Could the charging network in the Midwest be better? Sure. But at least it exists, and 250kW charging stations have really rolled out in the last few years.
The only reason to really use the nav anymore for trip planning, is that when it knows you're going to a fast charger it can precondition the battery so that it will charge as fast as possible and let you know when there's enough to continue the trip.

CCS cars probably do still need to do a bit more planning, but that's why a PHEV would be nice to have. Honda should just build a sporty car with a battery for daily range and peak performance and a little 660cc range extender motor.

By contrast Hydrogen fueling stations in the US only exist in California, and unless the only place out of California you want to go is Reno you're not going to have a very good time.

>>26237207
Not even all gas cars are good for long trips, especially not in places without infrastructure to support them.
EV infrastructure is getting pretty good in the US especially if you have a long range car with about 75kWh or more, and the ability to use both NACS and CCS.

Its not like gas stations instantly appeared everywhere the minute ICE cars were invented in the 1880s. It took decades for the status quo we enjoy now to emerge. Infrastructure for long recreational road trips in gas cars didn't really exist in North America till the 1950s 40 years after the first cars for the masses started appearing.
Affordable long range BEVs for the masses only really hit the market about 5 years ago, and they're already capable of long road trips if you want to use them that way.

If you can have one car, and you own a home. Buy a PHEV.
If you can have two cars, buy a short range BEV for daily use and whatever weekend vehicle you like.
If you don't own a home, buy a HEV.

If you're an enthusiast and you have the money, there's really no reason not to have a long range BEV as your daily car.

My Volt has an 83 HP 1.4 liter 4-cylinder and that feels like it's just barely adequate. posts.com:
In March 2000, auto sport Magazine of Japan’s front page carried the story that MTCI Racing Team would enter the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM for the upcoming JGTC season, the ultimate “GT1 prototype” racing against the Supras, Skylines, and NSXes. Little is known about the entry apart from Marco Apicella being appointed as the first driver.

However, somewhere along with the negotiations between MTCI and Mercedes-Benz, and perhaps in large part from the shame of the CLR’s massive failure at Le Mans in ‘99, the sale fell through. MTCI Racing Team would instead field a privately-built Porsche Boxster in GT300, with Apicella driving.

By season’s end, MTCI and its race team had collapsed into bankruptcy after the dot-com bubble burst. Chairman Yu Hayakawa was later arrested in 2002 for stock sales fraud. And save for its victory in the 1998 Suzuka 1000km, the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM never raced in Japan

Moslers actually raced in quite a few national-level GT championships like Grand-Am British, Belgian, Spanish, Australian GT series as well as Grand-Am, several SRO series, and a few rounds in FIA GT as an invite until the homologation rules made it so that a small-scale manufacturer could never be eligible for championship points. The car was fast, but also cheap to buy and cheap to run. It's downfall was not being eligible for homologation and just different series nerfing it because of its engine displacement.

The Japanese series would probably see the most of the different variants of the car through the years. It would have the original R, then the GT3 spec, and then the Judd-powered M.

>>26238810
A prototype did compete in 1994. Team Taisan is a stalwart in Japanese motorsports, having formed in 1983 as a privateer team and owned by the Taisan Industrial Company, a global manufacturer of electronic solenoid pumps.

The team enjoyed much racing success throughout the earlier Group A eras with a battery of Nissan R32 GT-Rs, along with BMW M3s in the lower JTCC series.

Business was clearly booming, as the team rocked up to the 1994 season fielding a Ferrari F40 and an ex-Group C Porsche 962 prototype (chassis 962-164). Consider the absurdity: a genuine Le Mans legend rubbing doors with tin-top GT cars. It was an impressive show of force, perfectly encapsulating the excess of Japan’s booming economy and well-heeled motoring enthusiasts. Over five rounds, Taisan’s Porsche 962C and Ferrari F40 won one meeting each, although the championship was ultimately won by Masahiko Kageyama in the Calsonic Hoshino Racing GT-R.

posts.com:
The ‘300ZX-GTS’ in these photos, chassis #009, is a little different than some of the earlier cars. For a start, it’s not twin-turbo V6-powered. Instead, a Nissan VH-series V8 can be found ahead of the quick-change rear end.

Whether it was a spare car or a development car is where things get a little bit murky, but it’s one of only two cars built by Cunningham Racing originally configured for use with the V8 engine, not retrofitted afterwards as other cars were. This would have allowed it to race in the 1995 IMSA GTS-1 class (the VG engine was outlawed at the end of the ’94 season), but the car was reportedly sold to Japan before it competed in any US events In 1997, it had been entered in a couple of JGTC GT500 class races wearing Fedex logos, but did not enjoy any success. Today, in its restored condition, it features the iconic Cunningham Racing 12 Hours of Sebring-winning livery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The rumble of a V8 in JGTC!

The sound of a roaring V8 and a distinct yellow figure, a sight that in 2002 was a far more familiar sight in the American Le Mans Series, but in that same year, the Autobacs All Japan GT Series had a similar sighting.

Entered by American car tuner ZIPSPEED, the Dunlop clad C4 was of a different breed to its more known Le Mans focused C5.R counterpart. Driven by Toshiyuki Yamamoto and Izumi Yoshida, the C4 struggled against its more suitable rivals, setting a 1:48.146 in its first qualifying session of 2002, in the All Japan GT Championship at Fuji Speedway and failing to qualify for the race while the polesitting #62 Vemac R&D Sport RD320R achieved a 1:32.379.

Four more races were attempted that year, however success never came the team's way, with the C4 making it to qualifying but never having enough speed to make the race.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The JGTC Honda that took on the 24 Hours of Nurburgring!

In 2004, a semi-works Honda programme enlisted a special car to take on the unique challenge that is the Green Hell. The team that year aimed for overall victory and as such acquired a car that could bring them that. That said car was the 2002 GT500 spec Honda NSX. The mid-engine car was already a proven victor in the All Japan Grand Touring Car Championship thanks to the three wins earned by Nakajima Racing, and one each by Mugen and Dome in the 2002 season.

The #3 Honda NSX was entered under the Sport Auto banner and was driven by Armin Hahne, Robert Lechner, Markus Oestreich, and Robin Liddell. A few changes were done to the car to accommodate Nurburgring and the length of the race. One of those changes was the V6 engine being down tuned from the JGTC regulated 500hp to 420hp for reliability. Other changes include endurance lights and Michelin tires of which the car never ran on in the JGTC. The NSX weigh a minimum of 1200kg as par the rules of A6, the class the Honda competed in at Nurburgring.

The #3 Sport Auto NSX had a small amount of kilometres under its belt before contesting the 24 Hours of Nurburgring. Lack of testing however didn't stop the German squad from placing inside the top 15 in qualifying, showing the potential of a JGTC car in uncharted territory. The NSX successfully started the race keeping up with the cars ahead of it which included DTM derived machinery from Audi and Opel. The car however experienced technical problems early in the race and completed 38 laps/7 hours before retiring. https://youtu.be/LRKIAK5Yw3w

Crossovers and EVs currently.
Full size body-on-frame SUVs with traditional longitudinal drivetrain have a purpose. Towing or plowing with a short wheelbase. Same with mid-size SUVs with the traditional longitudinal drivetrain for rough terrain and light towing. I am not a fan of rollover prone designs. Death traps are to be scrapped.
SUVs like the Escape, Equinox, MDX, Murano and Tucson are glorified AWD versions of FWD car drivetrains. Crossovers are soullessly designed. Many crossovers are garbage piles with plenty of failures and terrible to work on. Unibody full size SUVs share similar failures and repair difficulty. EVs require a reliance on Chinese lithium and chips, so they are not good for humanity. I am looking forward to golf cart level technology that can allow for easy diagnosis and repair. I don't want to be at the mercy of a touch screen going out and glitching or communist spyware. I've heard one too many stories of vehicles locking then catching on fire. I don't want Chinesium in my vehicle. Anything from there is problems.
What happened to NiMH technology no one talks about improving on? I heard a few big companies hold the patent and do not let anyone do anything with the technology.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26240493
>How do you determine a budget?
I think it comes down to a few things with varying priorities over others
>whats your take home pay?
>how much money do you have after all your post-tax bills are paid?
>how much savings do you have?
>do you intend on financing?
If someone had 10k in cash, a stable income, a reasonable amount of savings, then theres no reason why they couldn't put 10k down on a 20k car and have a small 10k loan that would come out to say 150 a month.

But you have any serious deficits in your financial well being then you can toss out a lot of these freedoms. If you have low wages or you don't have much money after your bills or you don't have much in savings, maybe your credit isn't that great.

>Yea I may have 50k saved, but that doesnt mean I should spend 50k or even 20k.
Absolutely correct, you may be more frivolous than others or more frugal. Maybe you create a budget for yourself in that you intend on spending 20k on a car and you have to reasonably justify how you allocate money. Maybe you're more frugal and think spending 20k of your 50k savings is unreasonable.

Its hard to look at this objectively and create a strict metric as to what it means to be able to afford something and be unable.

You calculate the monthly cost to you to own a car over 5 year period.

-$5000 (repairs/maintenance)

>spend $500 per year in maintenance (tires and new car warranty covers most issues)
>sell for $30k after 5 years
-$40000
-$1110 (222 x 5y)
-$2500 (500 x 5y)
+$30000
=
$12,611 net loss

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26240044
The rally is an off-road endurance event. The terrain that the competitors traverse is much tougher than that used in conventional rallying, and the vehicles used are typically true off-road vehicles and motorcycles, rather than modified on-road vehicles. Most of the competitive special sections are off-road, crossing dunes, mud, camel grass, rocks, and erg among others. The distances of each stage covered vary from short distances up to 800–900 kilometres (500–560 mi) per day. "Amateurs" typically struggle with the event. The rough terrain and lack of skill usually results in accidents and serious injuries.

The Dakar rally features a much greater variety of vehicles than traditional rally's, including bikes, quads, and trucks. Dominant manufacturers within the Dakar Rally are KTM for bikes, Yamaha for quads and Kamaz in trucks. Out of the big three Kamaz are most notable as they have won using the largest variety of vehicles instead of sticking with a select few models. In 2006 a tracked vehicle category was proposed and rejected due to the necessary volume of sub-divisions to ensure fair competition. In 2018 an EV category was proposed, this to was rejected as "there currently exists no electric vehicle capable of crossing the most remote stages of the Dakar unsupported and it would place an unnecessary risk on support crews to enable them to do so", despite annual reviews and counter-claims this continues to be the case. In 2020 Volkswagen proposed an all-electric entry for the 2021 race and although accepted as a non-competing entry, failed to appear.

>>26236247
Definitely check it out. The bolt has a 65KWH battery and the EV gets 259 miles (EUV slightly worse at 247). If you're getting 21 mpg that means you would have to buy 12 and a third gallons of gas to go 259 miles. Now you have to look up your electrical prices for off peak times. My off peak rate is about 8 cents per KWH and they have a special plan for EV drivers that lowers it down to about 6 cents per KWH. At 8 cents/KWH that comes out to $5.20 to go 259 miles. With current gas prices near me at 3.20 a gallon that comes out to be $39.46 to drive the same amount in your car. That is over 7.5 times cheaper. You said you spend 6k in fuel each year so you would be saving over 5k per year in fuel costs if you have similar electricity rates.

Shit, I do that. Pump the pedal three times to prime the carb, then open the throttle to keep it from flooding. Close it off most of the way as it catches to keep it from roaring to the limiter, but not all the way because it needs to warm the intake before it'll idle happy. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26240656
I'm not saying you don't plug it in. I'm saying that the car is constantly charging and discharging that bigger battery. Thats where the added fuel economy comes from. Dealerships and sales people quote these silly 42 miles and 18.1kWh numbers because they're just numbers. In reality the Toyota hybrid system never really lets the battery go below 20-30% and will charge the battery continuously when accelerating, going up kills, regenerative braking or coasting, etc. The Toyota software won't effectively let you drain that battery from 100% (which it doesn't let it charge to anyway) to near 0%.

>>26240028
Well now that saab is dead and buried, which is a good thing, finding parts isn't all that quick and easy anymore, although they're still available on ebay.
Dunno about the US but here in Europe you can't walk to the vatozone equivalent and assemble the whole car from spare parts anymore.

Mates saab cracked a valve at around 230k km, the first time, he ordered all the valves online and I replaced them for him, so I doubt it would happen that fast again, they were aftermarket valves too so they might actually hold worth a damn unlike the shitty factory ones.
If memory serves the piston rings were actually quite hard to come by for his engine, no one in europe had them readily available.

On topic of clutches, they're not really a problem in the NA variants, but in the turbo ones they tend to wear out quickly, especially if you send it yard like you're supposed to with a turbo car. They also don't really take well to extra power, but that's what aftermarket clutches are for.
Those later 900 had a transverse engine if memory serves, so they're not that bad with them like the older longitudinally mounted ones were.

Rust, there will be if you're not careful, then again it's not an OG 900 which were made out of wet tissue paper

>>26231373
Yes, it is. It's not that different from a regular W211 except for the engine which is reliable, much more reliable that the M156 that succeeded it.
The trans is an old 5-speed auto that can withstand 1000+ NM.
The air suspension is finicky, but not too expensive to fix.
You do get electrical gremlins, the heated/ventilated seats on mine don't work and I'm in the process of getting some electrical wiring and stuff from other W211s to fix it.
Also it consumes a bit of oil, but I'm not too worried since it was a bargain basically.
I love it, the torque is brutal, the acceleration is great, it's going toe to toe with much newer and more powerful cars. Did a dragy run when I bought it and it got 10s for 100-200km/h.
Though you need grip, powerful 4x4 will beat you from a standstil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26233381
I can't speak for the M3. But truth be told, the E46 is much more confidence inspiring. It feels a heck of a lot more planted and refined compared to the BRZ. It also helps the the non-M e46's have comparatively longer wheel bases and are open diff, making them a hell of a lot less twitchy compared to the BRZ. Steering feed back is fantastic due to the nature of hydraulic assist. But that said, the BRZ just feels overall better and more fun, Especially after you do headers and a flash tune to eliminate the dreaded torque dip. That said, if you like small low power cars to throw around, its an absolute riot compared to the e46. Me being fidgety makes throwing the car into gears really fun because of the really short gear ratio. The e46 around town comparatively feels boring because of its longer gearing. Both clutches are lightweight, so traffic isnt an issue, but the e46 also feels a hell of a lot more numb and sluggish. Shift feel in the BRZ is way better, e46 is sloppy like all BMWs of that era Honestly, I've been trying to modify the e46 to feel more like the BRZ, and that says something. Seating position on both cars is great compared to other cars. but in the e46 it feels like you sit too damn high and the steering wheel angle makes it feel like you're driving a semi.The BRZ is perfect out of the box. The seats are comfortable, and the pedals, steering wheel and shifter are all perfectly positioned. I havent tracked the E46 yet, and by the time the car is ready, i feel like it will be too damn heavily modified to give an accurate representation of stock vs stock.. The BRZ has its flaws, but the overall is a way better platform. Its much lighter stock, 2800 vs 3300lbs. And the chassis is stiffer right out of the box. The E46 is the better all rounder and a better daily. The chassis has potential, but its overall structurally too weak for abuse. You'd spend a lot of money reinforcing it and taking weight out of a car is much harder than adding power.

The Delorean. It is one of the shittest cars ever made. It's a 1980s sports car that had only 130hp and cost 25 grand. For reference you could get a Datsun 280zx for less than 10 grand and it had 180hp. Heck the Covette of 1981 was around 16 grand and it had 190hp. The Delorean was a complete and utter novelty of a car and nothing about it was salvageable. Until it was used in Back to the Future. That movie saved the car's reputation and nowadays it's viewed as this symbol of the 1980s. Don't let Delorean aficionados fool you, the car on it's own has no merits. It's a nice looking picture of a car. The movie is the car's entire reputation. Heck an original Delorean can't even do 88mph, the one in the film had it's engine swapped to a Porsche engine.

posts.com:
>>26234316
The non joke answer that doesn't involve games released 15 years ago is GRID: Legends for some sort of "motorsport progression" experience, Gran Turismo 7 is a bit of a disappointment if you're out for the Gran Turismo experience but it's not a bad game, Project Cars 2 if you want a slightly more simulator tier approach and a long career more spanning several types of car and track. Finally the Codies F1 games and Dirt Rally 2.0 are probably the best "single discipline" racing games but you may get bored of doing the same thing over and over. Whatever floats your boat there. Wreckfest is another really good option for racing something a bit more "random" like shitboxes and lawn mowers but genuinely fun.

For older games, Race07 is genuinely a great game to play but it is older and you'll need ALL DLC to have fun. The first GRID Game is also very good.

Finally for literally "racing" games WipEout is my personal favorite, alternatively RedOut 1 (not 2) and BallisticNG on PC are very good spiritual successors.

Assetto Corsa is only a good single player game if all you want to do is hotlap, drift and take screenshots. The AI is complete and utter garbage and even a reasonably slow driver will run circles around them. AMS2 is a scam at best. AMS1 is just reskinned rFactor (2005) and really only good for multiplayer (where it shines). Assetto Corsa Competizione has slightly better AI but the game is just so god damn boring to drive in my opinion and it takes a nuclear reactor of a PC to play. rFactor 2 is kinda ok for singleplayer but only on official tracks. Most usermade tracks confuse the AI and you'll run circles around them.

Any shoe you have that is classified as "minimalist" will work, just keep in mind minimalist shoes are different than your regular shoe if you try to do other things like walk or run in them compared to a normal shoe. On pedals though it's definitely the best compromise as they give you the feeling of where your feet and pedals are while still protecting your feet.

Here's mine I use for my pedals, I went with the FiveFingers because they have a better toe-feel when holding down the throttle so holding it down to full is a lot more intentional.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26240077
It's still an example of a minimalist shoe, which means less sole and cushion between your foot and whatever contact you have. You are correct though in that the variant I use is the one that leans towards bouldering and other trail activities, which if you're using exclusively as a pedal shoe is overkill. Definitely helps prevent the foot slipping off of the pedals though!

>>26240103
Swim shoes would work for this due to the fact they're a tight fitting shoe with very little sole. Really any sort of indoor minimalist shoe would work fine if it was just for pedals only since the tread pattern isn't a real concern and even an awful tread wouldn't be a concern. Only other thing I can think of regarding shoes is that the toe box could be different depending on what you're used to wearing, so it could be a bit different of a feeling if you put more pressure through the top of your foot rather than the bottom. That was what influenced my choice into the barefoot category of minimalist shoes.

If your car smells musty it's because there's mildew living in it somewhere. You need to find the source of it and actually clean it out and not try some bandaid gizmo "fix". First change your cabin air filter and make sure the evaporator box isn't filled with leaves and mold and crap.
If it continues to smell, take the seats out, shampoo them and shampoo the entire carpet. If it persists after that take the carpet out as well and bleach all the metal underneath. Check all your seals carefully and see if water is getting in somewhere, if so fix that as well.

posts.com:
>>26221414
>if you sell anything in a way that misrepresents its condition to the buyer, it is called fraud and is illegal.
This is true, however that doesn't mean you have to declare it.

If you sell the car 'as is' and don't declare the 2x on the tach that is legal, it is the responsibility of the prospective buyer to check out the car or get a mechanic to do so on their behalf.

If you are not selling the vehicle 'as is', declare the technical specs of the vehicle and deliberately omit the tach there's is grounds for fraud because you are deliberately omitting a known issue with the vehicle.

In either case, you must declare the fault if inquired, failure to do so is fraud.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26235667
realistically if you treat your car like an appliance that is roughly how long it will go. however, there are a lot of other factors such as the age and engine type, what part of the country its from, etc. it goes without saying that cars from the salted north don't last as long as those in the south, and a car with 200,000 miles that's had good care and maybe a couple owners could be just as good as a 80,000 mile car that just came off rental duty.
with even basic maintenance the 3.6 pentastar in the newer chrysler vans will go for much longer than that, you're far more likely to have a transmission failure because of the age and the general attitude of the auto industry to simply let trannies kill themselves (lel) with "lifetime" fluid that lasts just long enough to get the car out of powertrain warranty.

there is no hard cutoff where a car that does a certain number of miles just begins falling apart, but there are important, load bearing parts that are often difficult or expensive to get to that will cause a cascade of separate issues if not dealt with BEFORE the car gets there.
even something as simple as a timing cover gasket leak can lead to a catastrophic failure (usually fire).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237051
Looks decent, here is a list of things to confirm before buying the car

>A/C vent position working through all settings? (beware of blend door failure)
>headlamps don't randomly turn off by themselves (light module failure)
>engine is quiet and free of ticks / grinding / clanking noises?
>absolutely any suspicious noises on startup, especially the sound of a long metal chain slapping into the front cover of the engine?
>does the owner have maintenance receipts including oil changes?

That Town Car is a decent example, good color as well. Lack of A/C makes it more like a $2,500 car, not a $3,800 car, but in this inflated market, you may not have good luck. I would offer him $3,000. If he refuses, walk, and go buy a 2004 and up Grand Marquis

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26226080
Electric AWD is easy to achieve, just put an electric motor/generator on the front axle, which is also optimal for use with KERS. For a PHEV like this, that motor generator should let them eliminate a lot of complexity from the gas range extender engine as well since it will no longer need a traditional alternator, and they'll almost certainly have electric climate control as well, like using a heatpump to move heat from the powertrain to the cabin.

AWD with a MR layout pure ICE car requires you to have a driveshaft going from the transmission at the rear forward to the front axle. Its a lot harder to engineer and you don't get any advantages from doing it that way.
You may not like it from a philosophical purity perspective, but PHEV really is the best solution today.

>>26232529
Pickups benefited from one of the most successful lifestyle marketing campaigns ever devised by man, right below religious salvation, human rights, representative democracy, infinite compound growth, and unlimited borrowing into the future. It used to be that people bought them for the rugged appearance, bigger than you crash safety, and tough "get out of my way" looks, a popular persona adopted by frustrated commuters that are ten minutes late to work already.

These days people just want trucks, because they want trucks. The circular logic has now been firmly embedded into the public to the point where they don't really have a good reason beyond that. It's an extension of their identity, as evidenced by the immense aftermarkets available to personalize them.

Now, a few people do buy them for utility, but you won't find them in downtown Atlanta or the outer suburbs of LA. They're way out yonder in the middle of nowhere, where the only way to traverse the land reliably, no matter rain, sleet, snow, or apocalypse, is with a AWD or 4x4.

Personally, I like them, but wouldn't want to own one. They do make driving in 40+ mph crosswinds in the middle of a Midwest winter blizzard a lot easier though. Doing that in a compact car is an exercise in attrition, and General Winter always wins.
